sen.j: 伊射奈岐神社（いざなぎじんじゃ）は奈良県天理市にある神社。
sen.e: Izanagi-jinja Shirine is located in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
Izanagi-jinja Shirine is located in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
Izanagi-jinja Shirine is located in Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 崇神天皇近くの天神山に鎮座する。
sen.e: It is enshrined on Mt.Tenjin near the Mausoleum of Emperor Sujin.
sen.cmt: 「崇神天皇」と原文にありますが、英訳すると不自然なため、「崇神天皇陵」と訳してあります。
sen.e: It is located on Mt. Tenjin near the Mausoleum of Emperor Sujin.
It is located on Mt. Tenjin near the Mausoleum of Emperor Sujin.
History
History
History

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳にある城上郡の伊射奈岐神社に比定される。
sen.e: The shrine is identified as Izanagi-jinja Shirine in Shikinokaminokori in the Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan).
The shrine is identified as Izanagi-jinja Shrine in Shikinokaminokori in the Engishiki Jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan).
The shrine is identified as Izanagi-jinja Shrine in Shikinokaminokori in the Engishiki Jinmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan).

sen.j: 楊本天神、楊本天満宮と称し、かつては南東の山田垣内にあったといわれる。
sen.e: It was referred to as Yanagimoto Tenjin Shrine or Yanagimoto Tenmangu Shrine and was once located in Yamadagaichi in the southeast.
It was referred to as Yanagimoto Tenjin Shrine or Yanagimoto Tenmangu Shrine and was once located in Yamadagaichi in the southeast.
It was referred to as Yanagimoto Tenjin Shrine or Yanagimoto Tenmangu Shrine and was once located in Yamadagaichi in the southeast.

sen.j: 文明_(日本)年間には現在地に鎮座し、楊本の総鎮守とされていた。
sen.e: In the Bunmei era, it was located at its current place and was enshrined as Sochinju (local Shinto deity) of Yanagimoto.
In the Bunmei era, it was located at its current site and enshrined the sochinju (local Shinto deity) of Yanagimoto.
In the Bunmei era, it was located at its current site and enshrined the sochinju (local Shinto deity) of Yanagimoto.

sen.j: 寛正2年4月6日_(旧暦)（1461年5月24日）には興福寺大乗院主・尋尊が、天文_(元号)22年2月28日_(旧暦)（1553年4月20日）には三条西公条が参詣している。
sen.e: Jinson, the chief of Kofuku-ji Temple Daijo-in visited the shrine on May 24, 1461 and Kineda SANJONISHI visited on April 20, 1553.
Jinson, the chief of Kofuku-ji Temple Daijo-in visited the shrine on May 24, 1461 and Kineda SANJONISHI visited on April 20, 1553.
Jinson, the chief of Kofuku-ji Temple Daijo-in visited the shrine on May 24, 1461 and Kineda SANJONISHI visited on April 20, 1553.

sen.j: 同24年8月29日_(旧暦)（1555年9月24日）には後奈良天皇が綸旨を下し、8月だった神事を9月に定めるとともに、柳原淳光に皇室再興を祈らせた。
sen.e: On September 24, 1555, Emperor Gonara ordered the shrine to change its Shinto ritual from September to October, and also had Atsumitsu YANAGIWARA pray for revival of the Imperial Family.
sen.cmt: 原文の８月と９月は旧暦であると思われるためSeptemberとOctoberと訳してあります。
sen.e: On September 24, 1555, Emperor Go-Nara ordered the shrine to change its Shinto ritual from September to October, and also had Atsumitsu YANAGIWARA pray for revival of the Imperial Family.
On September 24, 1555, Emperor Gonara ordered the shrine to change its Shinto ritual from September to October, and also had Atsumitsu YANAGIWARA pray for revival of the Imperial Family.

sen.j: 江戸時代には柳本藩織田氏の庇護を受け、柳本藩社と呼ばれた。
sen.e: During the Edo period, it was under the patronage of the Oda clan of Yanagimoto Domain and was called Yanagimoto Domain Shrine.
During the Edo period, it was under the patronage of the Oda clan of Yanagimoto Domain and was called Yanagimoto Domain Shrine.
During the Edo period, it was under the patronage of the Oda clan of Yanagimoto Domain and was called Yanagimoto Domain Shrine.

sen.j: かつては神事は8月10日_(旧暦)に行なわれ、3斗が神楽料にあてられていた。
sen.e: The Shinto ritual was once held on August 10 (old lunar calendar) and 54 liters of rice was given for Kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines).
sen.cmt: 3斗は3斗の米と解釈し、訳してあります。
sen.e: The Shinto ritual was once held on August 10 (old lunar calendar) and 54 liters of rice was given for Kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines).
The Shinto ritual was once held on August 10 (old lunar calendar) and 54 liters of rice was given for Kagura (sacred music and dancing performed at shrines).

sen.j: 祭礼は簡素化されたが、明治初期まではサル束、キツネ束、ザクロ束などと呼ぶ7種類の御供を作って渡御をする神事があり、元亀2年8月10日_(旧暦)（1571年9月9日）に作られた御供用の板木2枚が残っていた。
sen.e: Although rites and festivals were simplified, there had been a togyo (a kind of Shinto rituals; transfer of a sacred object from its place of enshrinement) with seven kinds of attendants including Sarutsuka, Kitsunetsuka and Zakurotsuka until the early Meiji period; and there were two bangi (woodcuts) made for attendants on September 9, 1571.
sen.cmt: サル束、キツネ束、ザクロ束：定訳不明
sen.e: Although rites and festivals were simplified, a togyo (a Shinto ritual for the transfer of a sacred object from its place of enshrinement) with seven kinds of attendants including Sarutsuka, Kitsunetsuka and Zakurotsuka was held until the early Meiji period; and there were two bangi (woodcuts) made for attendants on September 9, 1571.

Although rites and festivals were simplified, a togyo (a Shinto ritual for the transfer of a sacred object from its place of enshrinement) with seven kinds of attendants including Sarutsuka, Kitsunetsuka and Zakurotsuka was held until the early Meiji period; and there were two bangi (woodcuts) made for attendants on September 9, 1571.

sen.j: 板木は桜で、1枚は表にアユ、裏にウメと蝦を、もう1枚にはコイが描かれる。
sen.e: The bangi were made from a cherry tree; one has a picture of ayu (a sweetfish) on the front and a picture of a Japanese plum with a shrimp on the back, and the other one has a picture of a carp.
The bangi were made from cherry wood; one has a picture of an ayu (sweetfish) on the front and a picture of a Japanese plum with a shrimp on the back, and the other one has a picture of a carp.
The bangi were made from cherry wood; one has a picture of an ayu (sweetfish) on the front and a picture of a Japanese plum with a shrimp on the back, and the other one has a picture of a carp.
Directions
Access
Access

sen.j: 西日本旅客鉄道桜井線柳本駅から徒歩5分
sen.e: A five-minute walk from Yanagimoto Station on the JR West Sakurai Line.
A five-minute walk from Yanagimoto Station on the JR West Sakurai Line.
A five-minute walk from Yanagimoto Station on the JR West Sakurai Line.
